awd_titl_txt: Spillovers from Price Regulations: Evidence from Rent Control in Cambridge, Massachusetts
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project investigates channels through which spillovers operate in the housing market by exploiting variation induced by the elimination of rent regulation. The project aims to improve our understanding of housing market externalities, the direct and indirect effects of price controls, and to take advantage of a unique policy experiment to explore core issues in urban economics such as the evolution of neighborhoods and the capitalization of amenities.

Several components of the project exploit a rich new data set on rent regulation in Cambridge MA.  The data set includes the precise location for all rent controlled units in Cambridge until 1995, when a statewide referendum eliminated rent control.  We link the data set to all housing market transactions in Cambridge and surrounding communities, building permitting activity, data from the City Census, which includes the identity, age and occupation of more than 80% of residents, and information on the credit profile of residents aggregated at a fine geographic level specific to rent controlled and non-rent controlled groups.  The project investigates the impact of the elimination of rent control on the prices of uncontrolled condominiums, single and multi-family housing.  Preliminary analysis suggests that there is a substantial impact of the elimination of rent control on the prices of uncontrolled houses in neighborhoods with large amounts of pre-existing rent controlled units.  We will carry out further analyses of the database to explore the reasons for the price change.  One mechanism involves changes in the level of building permitting activity due to investment complementarities between units, while the second involves measuring changes in the allocation of individuals to housing after the elimination of rent control.  Additional empirical work will examine the direct impacts of the end of rent regulation. 

Intellectual Merit:
The project documents previously unknown facts about the nature and extent of spillovers in the housing market.  It includes the development of new databases which allow for understanding various mechanisms which generate the spillovers. It raises new questions about measuring the welfare costs of price controls.

Broader Impact:
Regulations affecting housing markets are widespread and are often predicated on the existence of spillovers.  An improved understanding of the underlying forces generating spillovers in housing can help shape policies which influence housing investment and subsidies.  Moreover, price controls are present in many segments of the economy and an important aspect of these controls are the effects they have on uncontrolled sectors of the market. Finally, rent control is often considered a textbook example of how price controls affect the functioning of supply and demand. The detailed nature of our dataset allows for aspects of this research to be integrated into teaching.  The project will also support graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Neighborhood prosperity and neighborhood crime typically trend in opposite directions: affluent households rent or purchase in a neighborhood; criminal activity falls and amenities improve; rents rise; low income residents vacate; additional affluent residents enter, and so forth. It is easy to see how this process becomes self-reinforcing once underway. But are any of these factors—entry of affluent residents, falling crime, rising rents—sufficient to catalyze the full chain of events that culminates in gentrification? Many urban areas experienced a renaissance in the 1990s with rising house prices and falling crime rates. For instance, in Cambridge, MA real property values nearly doubled over this time period, which was twice the rate of increase that occurred simultaneously in the Boston Metropolitan Area. Our study tests whether the discontinuous and largely unanticipated elimination of rent control regulations in Cambridge in 1995 induced differential changes in property values and criminal activity in the neighborhoods where rent control was most binding.

 

We find robust evidence that the end of rent control in Cambridge was associated with a sharp differential reduction in criminal activity in formerly rent control-intensive areas of and this reduction in crime accounts for a substantial amount of the growth in residential property values. In our first paper, we found that approximately 25 percent of the increase in Cambridge property values was caused by the sudden end of rent control in 1995 (Autor, Palmer, and Pathak, 2014). In our second paper, we extend this framework using detailed, incident-level data on criminal activity assembled from Cambridge Police Department archives for the years 1992 through 2005. We estimate that rent decontrol caused overall crime to fall by 13 percent—approximately 900 reported crimes annually—with the majority of the effect accruing through reduced property crime. Applying external estimates of the economic costs of criminal victimization, we calculate that the annual direct benefit to potential victims from the reduction in crime between 1995 and 2005 was approximately $14 million in 2008 dollars. Capitalizing this flow into property values, this reduction accounts for 15 percent of the contemporaneous growth in the value of Cambridge residential properties that is attributable to rent decontrol. These results taken as a whole suggest that public safety improvements played a large role in the growth of property values in Cambridge in the post-rent control period of gentrification.

 

These results make several important broad contributions to our understanding of the effects of gentrification. First, while most studies of gentrification suffer from identification issues arising from the complexities of a social process like gentrification, the unique setting afforded by the quasi-experimental end of rent control in Massachusetts in 1995 provides a clear exogenous source of gentrification. Second, in our setting neighborhood variation in rent-control density prior to decontrol serves as a continuous measure of exposure to gentrification. Third, our geocoded incident-level crime data is a spatially granular representation of the changing geographic distribution of criminal activity in Cambridge. Finally, our work establishes the total change in property values induced by the end of rent control (Autor, Palmer, and Pathak, 2014), from which we can estimate the relative importance of the public-safety channel of neighborhood change in explaining the capitalization of the end of rent control into property values by combining our quasi-experimental estimates of the causal effect of gentrification on crime with independent external estimates of the monetary value of averted crime.
